questions.text: : A 68-year-old male who is hypertensive visited the doctor for a routine checkup. On auscultation, the doctor heard a systolic murmur well near the apex of the heart. This murmur is probably due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitral valve murmurs are best heard near the apex of the heart. A systolic murmur best heard in the mitral area occurs due to mitral regurgitation.

Explanation for other options:

Aortic Regurgitation(Option B): Aortic murmurs are best heard in the aortic region, as shown in the figure.

Mitral stenosis (Option C): Ventricular diastolic murmurs best heard in the mitral area are due to mitral stenosis.

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option D): Patent ductus arteriosus murmurs are continuously heard in systole and diastole.

questions.text: During a specific phase of the cardiac cycle, both the atrioventricular valves and semilunar valves are closed. During this phase, aortic pressure is at its minimum, and ventricular pressure begins to rise rapidly. This phase begins immediately after the end of which part of the atrial pressure curve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The isovolumetric contraction phase of ventricular systole begins after the end of atrial systole, which corresponds to the a wave in the atrial pressure (or JVP) curve.

During this phase:

  • Both AV and semilunar valves are closed.
  • Ventricular pressure rises rapidly, but volume remains constant.
  • Aortic pressure is at its lowest, just before the aortic valve opens.

choices.text: At the end of atrial systole
At the end of atrial diastole
At the beginning of ventricular diastole
At the end of rapid ejection phase

questions.text: The given graph illustrates volume changes during the cardiac cycle in correlation with the ECG and heart sounds.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The end of atrial systole marks the completion of ventricular filling, resulting in the maximum ventricular volume, known as End-Diastolic Volume (EDV). This occurs just before the QRS complex on ECG, initiating ventricular systole.

Explanation for other options:

At the end of atrial diastole (Option B): Atrial diastole occurs when the atria are filling; it does not contribute to ventricular filling.

At the beginning of ventricular diastole (Option C): By this point, ejection has already occurred, and volume is at its lowest.

At the end of the rapid ejection phase (Option D), Significant volume has already been expelled into the arteries — ventricular volume is decreasing, not maximal.

questions.text: The following figure shows some events in the cardiac cycle. Identify the appropriate event from it.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-mentioned figure shows atrioventricular valves are open, and the ventricles are filled with blood. So it is the ventricular filling phase.

  • At the same time, both atria are relaxed. So, only passive movement of blood from the atria to the ventricles is known as the passive filling phase of the ventricles.
  • Almost 70 % of blood moves from the atria to the ventricles in this phase.

Explanation for other options:

Isovolumetric relaxation of ventricles (Option A): In isovolumetric relaxation ventricles are a closed cavity, so no movement of blood on either side.
Active filling phase of ventricles (Option C): If the Atria are contracting at the same time, blood is actively pumped into the ventricles, so the so-called active filling phase of the ventricles.

questions.text: Observe the following diagram of the normal pressure-volume loop of the left ventricle. Identify the phase of the cardiac cycle from point c to point d.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the above diagram, to identify the phases, we need to observe the pressure and volume changes.
  • From point c to d, the pressure falls suddenly from approximately. 120 mmHg to nearly 0 mmHg. But the volume remains nearly 50 ml throughout the whole phase.
  • If the volume is the same, the ventricle acts as a closed cavity when the AV valve and semilunar valves are both closed. It is meant to be an isometric phase.
  • The pressure suddenly falls to nearly 0, suggesting it is a relaxation phase. So, from point c to d is an isometric relaxation phase.

Explanation for other options:

Isometric contraction phase (Option A): From point a to b, pressure rises without change in volume, showing the isometric contraction phase.

Slow filling phase of ventricles (Option C): During the diastolic phase, ventricles are filled with blood, with minimal pressure changes seen as from point d to a.

From point b to c, the volume falls from around 130 ml to 50 ml again, showing the emptying phase of the ventricle.

choices.text: Last rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole
Rapid passive filling phase of the diastole

questions.text: The third heart sound is typically not audible with a stethoscope under normal conditions. During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the third heart sound heard?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The third heart sound is produced by the vibrations of the ventricular valve due to the rushing of the blood from the atria.

  • In the 1stphase of ventricular diastole, when the AV valve opens up, blood rushes from the atria to the ventricle, setting up the vibrations in the ventricular wall, producing 3rdheart sound.
  • It is a low-pitch low low-frequency sound and coincides with T and P waves. Normally, it can be audible in individuals with a thin chest wall and those having good venous return.
  • During the last rapid filling phase of the ventricle, the blood rushes from the atria to the ventricles due to atrial systole, producing the 4th heart sound. (Option A ruled out)
  • The beginning of isometric contraction marks the 1st heart sound due to closure of AV valves (Option B ruled out)
  • The beginning of ventricular diastole marks the second heart sound due to closure of the emilunar valves. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Right atrial systole occurs before the left atrial systole
Right ventricular systole occurs after the left ventricular systole
Right ventricular ejection begins before the left ventricular ejection

questions.text: Events in the right side of the heart differs from the left heart as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Events occurring in the heart on both sides are nearly similar, but timings differ in some phases as follows:

  • The right atrial systole precedes the left atrial systole. (Option A)
  • Contraction of the right ventricle starts after the contraction of the left ventricle. (Option B)
  • Right ventricular ejection begins before that of the left ventricular ejection, because pulmonary arterial pressure is lower than aortic pressure. (Option C)

Key Takeaway: During inspiration, the aortic valve closes slightly before the pulmonary valve. The slower closure of the pulmonary valve is due to the lower impedance of the pulmonary vascular tree.

choices.text: Onset of QRS complex to the closure of aortic valves
Beginning of carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch

questions.text: Left ventricular function is affected in various cardiac diseases. A physician advised a 66-year-old male to investigate left ventricular contraction. The duration of electromechanical systole-QS2 in the left ventricle gives an idea about
questions.solution:
Explanation:

QS2 is the period from the onset of the QRS complex to the closure of the aortic valves, as determined by the onset of the second heart sound.

  • Measuring the duration of isovolumetric ventricular contraction is difficult in cardiac disorders.
  • The duration of total electromechanical systole (QS2), the pre-ejection period (PEP), and the left ventricular ejection time (LVET) will help to identify the left ventricular contractile function. It is measured by recording the ECG, phonocardiogram, and carotid pulse simultaneously.
  • LVET is the period from the beginning of the carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch.
  • PEP is the difference between QS2 and LVET and represents the time for the electrical as well as the mechanical events that precede systolic ejection.
  • The ratio of PEP/LVET increases when left ventricular performance is compromised. Normally, it is 35.

Explanation for other options:

Beginning of carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch (Option B): This corresponds to left ventricular ejection time (LVET)

Pre-ejection period (Option C): This is from Q wave to aortic valve opening, i.e., isovolumetric contraction period, not the entire systole.

Duration of ventricular repolarisation (Option D): This refers to the QT interval, not QS2. Ventricular repolarisation occurs after the peak of systole, making this unrelated to the QS2 interval.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Characteristics of pulse help us in diagnosing some disorders. Corrigan's pulse is a sign of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In aortic regurgitation, the aortic valve is incompetent. The pulse is very strong, and the force of systolic ejection generates a forceful pulse known as the water hammer pulse (Corrigan pulse)

  • The expansion of the arterial wall due to left ventricular contraction generates the pulse wave.

Explanation for other options:

Shock (Option A): In shock, the pulse is weak (thready) as the volume of ejection from the heart is very low.

COPD (Option C): In COPD, the pulse wave falls as the systolic pressure drops during inspiration and rises during expiration. It is called pulsus paradoxus.

Atrial flutter (Option D): May cause irregular heart rate, but not a specific pulse character like Corrigan's.

choices.text: Man has high cardiac efficiency than child
The cardiac efficiency of both is the same
The Child has higher efficiency than the man

questions.text: : A 35-year-old average (body surface area 1.6 square meter) male has a cardiac output of 6 litres per minute. A 4-year-old child has a cardiac output of 3 litres per minute, and the body surface area is 0.8 square meters. Compare the cardiac efficiency between this man and a child.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Cardiac efficiency of both is the same in the given scenario.

Cardiac output in any case is a good indicator of cardiac efficiency.

But to compare the cardiac efficiency in different age groups cardiac index is a better calculator for efficiency comparison.

Cardiac index can be measured by dividing cardiac output by body surface area for each individual.

For the man: CI=6 L/min1.6 m2

=3.75 L/min/m2

For the child: CI=3 L/min0.8 m2

=3.75 L/min/m2

Both have identical cardiac index values, so their cardiac efficiency is the same.

Explanation for other options:

The man has higher cardiac efficiency than the child (Option A): Absolute cardiac output is higher, but efficiency per BSA is equal.

The child has higher efficiency than the man (Option C): Cardiac index is the same.

Could not differentiate (Option D): The Cardiac index clearly allows comparison.

choices.text: Increasing the activity of the skeletal muscle pump

questions.text: Venous return plays a crucial role in maintaining cardiac output, as described by the Frank-Starling mechanism. Which of the following factor(s) contribute to an increase in venous return, thereby enhancing cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the limbs, the veins are surrounded by skeletal muscles, and contraction of these muscles during activity compresses the veins. Pulsations of nearby arteries may also compress veins.

  • Because the venous valves prevent reverse flow, the blood is pushed to the heart.
  • Pushing the blood to the heart increases the venous return.

The Frank-Starling mechanism states that the stroke volume of the heart increases in response to an increase in the volume of blood filling the heart (end-diastolic volume), because the heart muscle stretches more and contracts more forcefully.

Explanation for other options:

Increase in end diastolic volume (Option B): This is a result, not a cause, of increased venous return. While it contributes to increased stroke volume (by Frank-Starling), it's not a contributing factor to venous return itself.

Increase in contractility of ventricles (Option C): Ventricular contractility enhances stroke volume, but does not directly increase venous return. If afterload is low, it can reduce right atrial pressure and facilitate venous return, but it's indirect.

All of the above (Option D): Only option A directly contributes to venous return. B and C affect output, not return.

questions.text: Cardiac output is an important measure of the efficiency of the heart. Among the following, which method cannot be used in humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the electromagnetic flow meter, the instrument is directly placed into the aorta. It is done only in experimental animals. Riskier in humans.

Explanation for other options:

Direct Fick method (Option A): According to the Fick principle, the amount of substance taken up by an organ per unit time is the same as the arterial level of the substance minus the venous level, times the blood flow.

  • CO = Cardiac Output
  • Ca = Oxygen content of arterial blood
  • Cv = Oxygen content of mixed venous blood
  • VO2 = Oxygen consumption in mL of pure gaseous oxygen per minute.

Indicator dilution method (Option B): A known amount of dye is injected, usually a radioactive isotope, into the vein, and then a series of samples taken from arterial blood is plotted in the graph against time as the concentration rises, falls, and then rises again as the indicator recirculates.

Doppler with echocardiography (Option D): Doppler with echocardiography will give ideas about the blood flowing in and out of each chamber of the heart. Blood flowing out of the left ventricle times the heart rate gives cardiac output.

Key Takeaway: In the electromagnetic flow meter [CO = Stroke Volume (SV) x Heart Rate (HR)], the instrument is directly placed into the aorta. It is done only in experimental animals. Riskier in humans.

questions.text: The sympathetic system influences the activity of the heart via T1 to T5 segments of the spinal cord. The effect is an increase in the force of contraction of the heart, also known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The increase in sympathetic stimulation increases the activities of the heart, like force of contraction, heart rate, excitability of the heart and also conductivity in the heart. An increase in force of contraction (effect on heart muscle) is known as inotropic action on the heart. It increases stroke volume and thus cardiac output.

Explanation for other options:

Bathmotropic action (Option A): An Increase in excitability of the heart is known as positive bathmotropic action of the heart.

Chronotropic action (Option B): An increase in heart rate with sympathetic stimulation (via pacemaker stimulation) is known as chronotropic action.

Dromotropic action (Option C): An Increase in the rate of conduction of an impulse is called dromotropic action on the heart.

questions.text: A venous return to the heart influences the cardiac output via changing the end diastolic volume. Which of the following factor/s decrease/s the venous return?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The amount of blood returning to the heart, that is, venous return, increases the end diastolic volume proportionately.
  • An increase in negative intrathoracic pressure increases the pressure gradient along which blood flows to the heart. It increases the venous return. A decrease in this pressure reduces the venous return.

Explanation for other options:

Venoconstriction (Option A): It causes contraction of reserved blood from the veins into the circulation, thus reducing the venous pooling and increasing the venous return.

Pumping action of skeletal muscle (Option C): Prolonged standing pools the blood in the peripheral veins, thus reducing the venous return. While lower limb activity causes the muscle to contract, the deep veins between the muscles are compressed and direct the blood flow to the heart.

Increase in blood volume (Option D): An increase in blood volume increases the venous return.

questions.text: Following is/are the feature of systolic failure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heart failure can be systolic failure or diastolic failure.

  • In systolic failure, the systolic dysfunction leads to a decrease in stroke volume because the ventricles do not contract efficiently. It causes an increase in end-systolic volume. Further ejection fraction is reduced from normal 65% to as low as 20 %. (Option A is true)
  • Initially, due to systolic failure, the genes that cause hypertrophy of cardiac muscles are activated. So the thickness of the ventricular wall increases, leading to cardiac remodelling. (Option B is true)
  • A decrease in filling of the arterial system increases discharge from the sympathetic system, also increasing renin and aldosterone secretion, leading to sodium and water retention. (Option C is true)

Key Takeaway:

Feature of systolic failure:

  • Increase in end-systolic volume
  • Cardiac remodeling
  • Na+ and water retention

questions.text: : A 57-year-old patient has undergone a heart transplant due to heart failure. After the transplant, the cardiac responses are recorded in the patient to moderate exercise. Which of the following parameters does not change in the patient with exercise compared to normal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A transplanted heart is denervated. It does not have neural input. So it depends primarily on the increase in stroke volume with exercise.
  • The heart rate does not change in response to exercise, as it is increased by sympathetic stimulation.

Explanation for other options:

O2 consumption (Option A): With exercise, the need for oxygen increases. It is fulfilled by an increase in respiratory activity.

Cardiac output (Option B) Cardiac output is equal to stroke volume multiplied by heart rate. As the stroke volume increases, the output increases even though the heart rate does not change.

Stroke volume (Option D): The heterometric regulation or intrinsic regulation, according to Frank Starling's law, the stroke volume increases due to an increase in venous return and end diastolic volume of blood. Thus increases the stroke volume.

Key Takeaway:

The heart rate does not change in response to exercise, as it is increased by sympathetic stimulation.

choices.text: Preload causes a greater increase in cardiac O2 consumption than does an increase in Afterload
Aortic stenosis increases the afterload to the heart
Afterload for the myocardium is best represented by aortic pressure during systole
Afterload is the force the ventricle must overcome to eject blood into the circulation

questions.text: Preload and afterload are very important to understand for cardiac pumping mechanisms. Among the following, which is not true about afterload?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An increase in afterload causes a greater increase in myocardial oxygen consumption compared to preload.

  • Cardiac output depends on preload, afterload, and contractility.
  • Preload to the heart muscles is the load applied before the ventricular systole. Preload to the heart is the end diastolic volume. As preload increases, the force of contraction increases.
  • Afterload to the heart is the load applied to the cardiac muscles during contraction. Peripheral resistance is the afterload for the heart muscle (ventricular muscles)
  • A 25% increase in stroke volume without a change in arterial pressure will produce the same increase in O2 consumption as vice versa.
  • Peripheral resistance increases the O2 consumption more than volume.
  • In aortic stenosis, the left ventricle must generate higher pressure to overcome the narrowed aortic valve, increasing afterload. (Option B ruled out)
  • Afterload is best approximated by aortic pressure during systole, which represents the pressure the ventricle must work against. (Option C ruled out)
  • Afterload refers to the force the heart (ventricle) must overcome to eject blood into the aorta or pulmonary artery (the arterial pressure or vascular resistance). (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Postural change from standing to supine

questions.text: Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped out by the ventricles per minute. Many factors affect the cardiac output. Which of the following factors decreases cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardiac output is a product of stroke volume and heart rate. Depression decreases myocardial contractility via decreasing sympathetic activity, causing a decrease in cardiac output.

Explanation for other options:

Postural change from standing to supine (Option A): Postural change suddenly from standing to supine reduces the anti-gravity effect on venous return, so venous return increases from standing to supine. It causes an increase in end-diastolic volume (EDV). According to Frank-Starling's law, EDV increases cardiac output.

Moderate increase in temperature (Option C): A Moderate increase in temperature increases the metabolic requirement of the body, thus increasing the cardiac output.

Anxiety (Option D): Anxiety stimulates sympathetic activity, causing an increase in heart rate and stroke volume, so cardiac output increases.

Key Takeaway:  Depression decreases myocardial contractility via decreasing sympathetic activity, causing a decrease in cardiac output.
